anns.prefix: Here, for the soil actinobacterium Streptomyces lincolnensis, we describe a fundamentally new ribosome-mediated signaling cascade that accelerates the onset of
anns.postfix: production in response to an external ribosome-targeting antibiotic to synchronize antibiotic production within the population.

anns.prefix: The entire cascade is encoded in the
anns.postfix: biosynthetic gene cluster (BGC) and consists of three lincomycin resistance proteins in addition to the transcriptional regulator LmbU: a lincomycin transporter (LmrA), a 23S rRNA methyltransferase (LmrB), both of which confer high resistance, and an ATP-binding cassette family F (ABCF) ATPase, LmrC, which confers only moderate resistance but is essential for antibiotic-induced signal transduction.

anns.prefix: Specifically, antibiotic sensing occurs via ribosome-mediated attenuation, which activates LmrC production in response to lincosamide,
anns.postfix: , or pleuromutilin antibiotics.

anns.prefix: Then, ATPase activity of the ribosome-associated LmrC triggers the transcription of lmbU and consequently the expression of
anns.postfix: BGC.

anns.prefix: Streptomycete-derived macrolide,
anns.postfix: , lincosamide, and streptogramin antibiotics target the peptidyl transferase center (PTC) of the 50S ribosomal subunit or structures in proximity to it (adjacent A- and P-sites or ribosomal exit tunnel).

anns.prefix: Streptomycete-derived macrolide,
anns.postfix: , lincosamide, and streptogramin antibiotics target the peptidyl transferase center (PTC) of the 50S ribosomal subunit or structures in proximity to it (adjacent A- and P-sites or ribosomal exit tunnel).

anns.prefix: In this study, we used the
anns.postfix: BGC as a model BGC encoding three resistance proteins: LmrA, LmrB, and LmrC (Fig. 1a) (23).

anns.prefix: We show that all Lmr proteins confer a certain level of resistance to lincosamides; however, only the LmrA transporter and partially the LmrB 23S rRNA methyltransferase were required for the self-protection from the produced
In contrast and more importantly, we revealed that the LmrC ABCF ATPase is dispensable for self-protection, but it is a key component of an antibiotic-induced cascade, which directs the onset of
anns.postfix: biosynthesis through a transcriptional regulator, LmbU (24, 25), and in cooperation with LmrA and LmrB resistance proteins.

anns.prefix: To interpret the role of the three resistance proteins encoded in the
anns.postfix: BGC, we first evaluated the contribution of the individual proteins to the resistance.

anns.prefix: Specifically, we knocked out lmrA, lmrB, and lmrC singly or in pairs in the
anns.postfix: S. lincolnensis wild-type (WT) strain (Fig. 1b) and, in addition, we complemented the genes under the control of a constitutive or natural promoter acting in trans (see Fig. S1).

anns.prefix: Then, we evaluated the resistance phenotype of the WT, knockout, and complemented strains by determining the MICs of
anns.postfix: and its derivative, clindamycin.

We revealed that all strains bearing lmrA, including the strains with lmrA only (Fig. 1b, S. lincolnensis strains WT, ΔC, ΔB, and ΔBC; Fig. 1c, S. coelicolor strains ACC and AC), were highly or extremely resistant to
anns.postfix: , while the resistance to lincomycin significantly decreased when lmrA was absent regardless of other two resistance genes were present.

anns.prefix: Interestingly, the resistance to
anns.postfix: , generally a more efficient semisynthetic derivative of lincomycin, is different in this respect.

anns.prefix: Interestingly, the resistance to clindamycin, generally a more efficient semisynthetic derivative of
anns.postfix: , is different in this respect.

anns.prefix: Specifically, the majority of the tested strains were moderately resistant to
anns.postfix: with no or little contribution of LmrA to the resistance (Fig. 1b, compares the strains differing in lmrA only: ΔB versus ΔAB, WT versus ΔA, and ΔC versus ΔAC, and Fig. 1c, AC versus M1154+pIJ10257).

anns.prefix: Therefore, we assume that LmrA, a transporter of the major facilitator family, is highly specific to
anns.postfix: but not clindamycin, and it ensures sufficient self-resistance to the produced lincomycin on its own.

anns.prefix: Given the newly defined function of ABCF proteins as modulators of ribosomal PTC, the onset of
anns.postfix: production in response to antibiotics might be regulated by LmrC. To uncover the role of LmrC, we performed comparative mass spectrometry proteomic analysis of the mycelia of S. lincolnensis WT, WT+Cc, and ΔC strains grown in the absence or presence of clindamycin.

anns.prefix: As shown in Fig. 3a,
anns.postfix: supplementation increased the abundance of lincomycin BGC proteins in both the WT (namely, proteins of the lmbUXYB operon) and WT+Cc (the whole BGC), while in the ΔC strain, lincomycin BGC proteins were more abundant in cultures without clindamycin.

anns.postfix: induced transcription of lmrC, lmbU, and lmbN, which was not under the direct control of lmbU, in the WT strain but not in the lmrC-deficient ΔC knockout strain.

anns.prefix: Several recent studies described regulators of
anns.postfix: biosynthesis encoded outside the BGC in the S. lincolnensis genome (28–31).

anns.prefix: Some of these conserved global regulators might be involved in the antibiotic-induced onset of
anns.postfix: production in addition to LmrC. To rule out this hypothesis, we cloned the lincomycin BGC region starting upstream of lmrC and ending with lmbU translationally fused with the mCherry reporter (C-U-mCh) and introduced it into S. coelicolor M145.

anns.prefix: As expected, the induced production of the mCherry reporter in response to
anns.postfix: was detected only in the strain with the full-length C-U-mCh construct, while in the strain with the truncated lmrC gene (U-mCh), the level of mCherry expression did not change after clindamycin induction.

anns.prefix: From these data, we concluded that lmbU expression, and thus the onset of
anns.postfix: production in response to antibiotics, is mainly triggered by lmrC. However, we cannot completely exclude the possibility that S. coelicolor homologs of global regulators that contribute to lincomycin biosynthesis in S. lincolnensis, such as AdpA and BldD (32, 33), also affect the expression of lmrC and lmbU in S. coelicolor.

anns.prefix: Since LmrA confers high-level resistance only to
anns.postfix: (Fig. 1b; see also Fig. S1), there was a considerably higher level of LmrC in the WT induced by clindamycin than in the WT induced by lincomycin (Fig. 4a and b), which may reflect the fact that only lincomycin is exported by the LmrA transporter; thus, the low intracellular levels are maintained (37).

anns.prefix: Indeed, deletion of lmrA (ΔA) resulted in comparable levels of LmrC expression induced by either
anns.postfix: or clindamycin (Fig. 4d).

anns.prefix: LmrA thus specifically dampens the LmrC production induced by
anns.postfix: by reducing its intracellular concentration.

anns.postfix: biosynthesis.

In this study, we characterized an LSAP antibiotic-driven signaling cascade for the activation of the onset of
anns.postfix: biosynthesis, in which an antibiotic resistance protein, LmrC, from the ARE5 subfamily of ABCF proteins is the key signal-transducing element (Fig. 6a).

anns.prefix: The major novelty of this cascade lies in the dual antibiotic resistance and regulatory function of the ABCF protein LmrC, which transduces the antibiotic signal to the expression of LmbU and promotes
anns.postfix: biosynthesis.

anns.prefix: In addition, we show that another two
anns.postfix: BGC-encoded resistance proteins, LmrB and LmrA, affect the cascade by dampening the LSAP antibiotic-induced expression of lmrC. We assume that LmrB, due to its position in the lmbUXY-lmrB operon with two biosynthetic genes, mediates a direct negative feedback loop of the cascade.

anns.prefix: The LmrA transporter links
anns.postfix: biosynthesis to the primary metabolic pathways since it is regulated by the GlnR global regulator (37).

anns.prefix: LmrA seems to be the most important component for

anns.prefix: In this study, we characterized an LSAP antibiotic-driven signaling cascade for the activation of the onset of
anns.postfix: biosynthesis, in which an antibiotic resistance protein, LmrC, from the ARE5 subfamily of ABCF proteins is the key signal-transducing element (Fig. 6a).

anns.prefix: The major novelty of this cascade lies in the dual antibiotic resistance and regulatory function of the ABCF protein LmrC, which transduces the antibiotic signal to the expression of LmbU and promotes
anns.postfix: biosynthesis.

anns.prefix: In addition, we show that another two
anns.postfix: BGC-encoded resistance proteins, LmrB and LmrA, affect the cascade by dampening the LSAP antibiotic-induced expression of lmrC. We assume that LmrB, due to its position in the lmbUXY-lmrB operon with two biosynthetic genes, mediates a direct negative feedback loop of the cascade.

anns.prefix: The LmrA transporter links
anns.postfix: biosynthesis to the primary metabolic pathways since it is regulated by the GlnR global regulator (37).

anns.prefix: LmrA seems to be the most important component for
anns.postfix: production because lincomycin biosynthesis is remarkably suppressed when LmrA is not present.

anns.prefix: Furthermore, LmrA, as a
anns.postfix: transporter, desensitizes the cascade specifically to lincomycin, which may prevent the products from reactivation the biosynthesis when it is no longer desirable.

anns.prefix: The regulatory pair of LmbU and LmrC is unique to
anns.postfix: BGC; no other known BGC encodes a LmbU-family regulator together with an ABCF protein.

anns.prefix: It was previously shown that LmbU directly activates only the 4-alkyl-l-proline biosynthesis-encoding part of
anns.postfix: BGC (24), which is also evident from our proteomic data (Fig. 3a).

anns.prefix: In contrast, the recently described regulator of
anns.postfix: BGC, AdpAlin, activates the entire lincomycin BGC independently of the external lincosamide and thus appears to be the principal regulator of lincomycin biosynthesis (28).

anns.prefix: This signaling cascade may, in response to the extracellular
anns.postfix: secreted by neighboring cells, induce a premature onset of lincomycin production to ensure its synchronous biosynthesis in a wider population, thereby achieving an ecologically efficient lincomycin concentration similar to that proposed for the biosynthesis of the cell wall inhibiting lantibiotic planosporicin (49) or actinorhodin (50).

anns.prefix: Substantially reduced production of
anns.postfix: in the lmrB-overexpression strain (Fig. 4b) after antibiotic induction showed that the binding of the antibiotic to the ribosome is a prerequisite for the induction of LmrC production.

could thus be regulated by a ribosome-mediated attenuation mechanism as described previously for other antibiotic-resistant ABCF proteins (38–40): in the absence of antibiotics, either the formation of a premature terminator in the 5′ untranslated region (5′UTR) or the inaccessibility of ribosome binding site (RBS) prevent gene expression.

anns.prefix: In addition to
anns.postfix: , which belongs to the ARE5 subfamily, the genome of S. lincolnensis encodes eight ABCF proteins, three of which have putative resistance activity (ARE5 encoded by SLINC_7152 and two AAF4 encoded by SLINC_1109 and SLINC_6197).

anns.postfix: DISCUSSION Antibiotic resistance proteins associated with BGCs have traditionally been perceived as a means of self-protecting mechanisms.

anns.prefix: In this study, we characterized an LSAP antibiotic-driven signaling cascade for the activation of the onset of lincomycin biosynthesis, in which an antibiotic resistance protein,
anns.postfix: , from the ARE5 subfamily of ABCF proteins is the key signal-transducing element (Fig. 6a).

anns.prefix: The major novelty of this cascade lies in the dual antibiotic resistance and regulatory function of the ABCF protein
anns.postfix: , which transduces the antibiotic signal to the expression of LmbU and promotes lincomycin biosynthesis.

anns.prefix: The major novelty of this cascade lies in the dual antibiotic resistance and regulatory function of the ABCF protein LmrC, which transduces the antibiotic signal to the expression of
anns.postfix: and promotes lincomycin biosynthesis.

anns.prefix: In addition, we show that another two lincomycin BGC-encoded resistance proteins,
anns.postfix: and LmrA, affect the cascade by dampening the LSAP antibiotic-induced expression of lmrC. We assume that LmrB, due to its position in the lmbUXY-lmrB operon with two biosynthetic genes, mediates a direct negative feedback loop of the cascade.

anns.prefix: In addition, we show that another two lincomycin BGC-encoded resistance proteins, LmrB and
anns.postfix: , affect the cascade by dampening the LSAP antibiotic-induced expression of lmrC. We assume that LmrB, due to its position in the lmbUXY-lmrB operon with two biosynthetic genes, mediates a direct negative feedback loop of the cascade.

anns.prefix: ABSTRACT In natural environments,

anns.prefix: Here, for the soil actinobacterium Streptomyces lincolnensis, we describe a fundamentally new ribosome-mediated signaling cascade that accelerates the onset of lincomycin production in response to an external ribosome-targeting
anns.postfix: to synchronize antibiotic production within the population.

anns.prefix: The entire cascade is encoded in the lincomycin biosynthetic gene cluster (BGC) and consists of three lincomycin resistance proteins in addition to the transcriptional regulator LmbU: a lincomycin transporter (LmrA), a 23S rRNA methyltransferase (LmrB), both of which confer high resistance, and an ATP-binding cassette family F (ABCF) ATPase, LmrC, which confers only moderate resistance but is essential for
anns.postfix: signal transduction.

anns.prefix: Specifically,
anns.postfix: sensing occurs via ribosome-mediated attenuation, which activates LmrC production in response to lincosamide, streptogramin A, or pleuromutilin antibiotics.

anns.prefix: Specifically, antibiotic sensing occurs via ribosome-mediated attenuation, which activates LmrC production in response to lincosamide, streptogramin A, or pleuromutilin
Finally, the production of LmrC is downregulated by LmrA and LmrB, which reduces the amount of ribosome-bound
anns.postfix: and thus fine-tunes the cascade.

anns.prefix: We propose that analogous ABCF-mediated signaling systems are relatively common because many ribosome-targeting
anns.postfix: BGCs encode an ABCF protein accompanied by additional resistance protein(s) and transcriptional regulators.

anns.prefix: Moreover, we revealed that three of the eight coproduced ABCF proteins of S. lincolnensis are clindamycin responsive, suggesting that the ABCF-mediated
anns.postfix: signaling may be a widely utilized tool for chemical communication.

anns.prefix: For instance, streptomycetes produce two-thirds of the clinically used
anns.postfix: of natural origin.

anns.prefix: The current concept is that

anns.prefix: From these data, we concluded that lmbU expression, and thus the onset of lincomycin production in response to

anns.prefix: Substantially reduced production of LmrC in the lmrB-overexpression strain (Fig. 4b) after
anns.postfix: induction showed that the binding of the antibiotic to the ribosome is a prerequisite for the induction of LmrC production.

anns.prefix: LmrC could thus be regulated by a ribosome-mediated attenuation mechanism as described previously for other
anns.postfix: ABCF proteins (38–40): in the absence of antibiotics, either the formation of a premature terminator in the 5′ untranslated region (5′UTR) or the inaccessibility of ribosome binding site (RBS) prevent gene expression.

anns.prefix: LmrC could thus be regulated by a ribosome-mediated attenuation mechanism as described previously for other antibiotic-resistant ABCF proteins (38–40): in the absence of
anns.postfix: , either the formation of a premature terminator in the 5′ untranslated region (5′UTR) or the inaccessibility of ribosome binding site (RBS) prevent gene expression.

anns.prefix: In the presence of
anns.postfix: , inhibited ribosomes stall during translation of the upstream regulatory open reading frame (uORF), which promotes the alteration of the 5′UTR secondary structure and thereby releases gene expression (41).

anns.prefix: Indeed, an in silico analysis of the lmrC upstream region revealed two putative promoters and two premature terminators with the ability to form alternative

anns.prefix: In summary, the
anns.postfix: control of lmrC expression occurs via the formation of a premature terminator structure, which prevents lmrC expression in the absence of an antibiotic.

anns.postfix: , which is required for high production (50, 54), or is mediated by a cognate antibiotic-recognizing repressor that, in addition to the regulation of transporter, also regulates biosynthetic genes (55).

anns.prefix: In contrast, LmrC appears to directly transduce the
anns.postfix: signal to lmbU transcription while conferring low antibiotic resistance.

anns.prefix: Thus, LmrC has a dual function:
anns.postfix: and regulation, but it is also possible that the low LmrC-mediated resistance is only an indirect consequence of the primary antibiotic signal transduction function and that its biological significance is minor.

anns.prefix: Thus, LmrC has a dual function: resistance and regulation, but it is also possible that the low LmrC-mediated resistance is only an indirect consequence of the primary
anns.postfix: signal transduction function and that its biological significance is minor.

anns.prefix: Notably, LmrC, as well as other ABCF proteins implicated in
anns.postfix: in streptomycetes, shares the antibiotic resistance domain ARD with structurally characterized antibiotic resistance ABCF proteins, VmlR, MsrE, VgaALC, VgaL, and LsaA from Firmicutes.

anns.prefix: The ARD interacts with PTC to dislodge the
anns.postfix: from the ribosome (34, 35, 56, 57) (Fig. 6c), and it is present in the majority of antibiotic-resistant ABCF proteins but not in EttA and other putative regulatory ABCFs (22).

anns.prefix: The ARD interacts with PTC to dislodge the antibiotic from the ribosome (34, 35, 56, 57) (Fig. 6c), and it is present in the majority of
anns.postfix: ABCF proteins but not in EttA and other putative regulatory ABCFs (22).

anns.prefix: In addition to ARD, LmrC also has the arm domain, which is absent in
anns.postfix: ABCFs but is present in the EttA translation regulator (20).

anns.prefix: In addition to LmrC, another two ABCF proteins were induced by clindamycin in S. lincolnensis (Fig. 3a), which is a strong indication that ABCF proteins not associated with BGCs for PTC-targeting
anns.postfix: may also have an antibiotic-responsive regulatory function.

anns.prefix: In addition to LmrC, another two ABCF proteins were induced by clindamycin in S. lincolnensis (Fig. 3a), which is a strong indication that ABCF proteins not associated with BGCs for PTC-targeting antibiotics may also have an
anns.postfix: regulatory function.

anns.prefix: The signaling pathway described here, in which the antibiotic signal is sensed and transduced by the dual, resistance, and regulatory ABCF proteins and tuned by two other resistance proteins, points out the need to reconsider the role of
anns.postfix: ABCF proteins as purely protective mechanisms.

anns.prefix: We revealed that all strains bearing
anns.postfix: , including the strains with lmrA only (Fig. 1b, S. lincolnensis strains WT, ΔC, ΔB, and ΔBC; Fig. 1c, S. coelicolor strains ACC and AC), were highly or extremely resistant to lincomycin, while the resistance to lincomycin significantly decreased when lmrA was absent regardless of other two resistance genes were present.

anns.prefix: Specifically, the majority of the tested strains were moderately resistant to clindamycin with no or little contribution of LmrA to the resistance (Fig. 1b, compares the strains differing in
anns.postfix: only: ΔB versus ΔAB, WT versus ΔA, and ΔC versus ΔAC, and Fig. 1c, AC versus M1154+pIJ10257).

anns.prefix: Specifically, the majority of the tested strains were moderately resistant to clindamycin with no or little contribution of LmrA to the resistance (Fig. 1b, compares the strains differing in
anns.postfix: only: ΔB versus ΔAB, WT versus ΔA, and ΔC versus ΔAC, and Fig. 1c, AC versus M1154+pIJ10257).

anns.prefix: However, when naturally expressed in S. lincolnensis, it confers a significant level of resistance to clindamycin alone (Fig. 1b, compares strains differing only in
anns.postfix: versus ΔB, ΔC versus ΔBC, and ΔA versus ΔAB).

anns.prefix: From these data, we concluded that
anns.postfix: expression, and thus the onset of lincomycin production in response to antibiotics, is mainly triggered by lmrC. However, we cannot completely exclude the possibility that S. coelicolor homologs of global regulators that contribute to lincomycin biosynthesis in S. lincolnensis, such as AdpA and BldD (32, 33), also affect the expression of lmrC and lmbU in S. coelicolor.

anns.prefix: Here, for the soil actinobacterium
anns.postfix: , we describe a fundamentally new ribosome-mediated signaling cascade that accelerates the onset of lincomycin production in response to an external ribosome-targeting antibiotic to synchronize antibiotic production within the population.

anns.prefix: Moreover, we revealed that three of the eight coproduced ABCF proteins of
anns.postfix: are clindamycin responsive, suggesting that the ABCF-mediated antibiotic signaling may be a widely utilized tool for chemical communication.

anns.prefix: KEYWORDS INTRODUCTION INTRODUCTION The genus
anns.postfix: and several other related genera of Actinobacteria (here referred to as streptomycetes) are filamentous soil and marine bacteria characterized by a remarkably rich specialized metabolism.

anns.prefix: KEYWORDS INTRODUCTION INTRODUCTION The genus Streptomyces and several other related genera of
anns.postfix: (here referred to as streptomycetes) are filamentous soil and marine bacteria characterized by a remarkably rich specialized metabolism.

anns.postfix: contain the highest proportion of biosynthetic gene clusters (BGCs) per Mb among all bacteria (1).

anns.prefix: The
anns.postfix: ΔA (BN3024), S. lincolnensis ΔB (BN3002), and S. lincolnensis ΔC (BN3001) mutants were constructed by replacing the entire coding sequence of the target gene with a cassette (773 or 775 [62]) carrying the apramycin resistance gene [aac(3)IV] and oriT of RK2 using the PCR-targeting method (63).

anns.prefix: After conjugation of mutated cosmids into
anns.postfix: , kanamycin-sensitive (Kans) and apramycin-resistant (Aprr) double-crossover mutants with target genes replaced by the aac(3)IV-oriT cassette were confirmed by PCR amplification.

anns.prefix: For the construction of
anns.postfix: ΔAB (BN3021), S. lincolnensis ΔAC (BN3018), and S. lincolnensis ΔBC (BN3008) double mutants, the inactivation cassettes 773 in S. lincolnensis ΔB (BN3002) and S. lincolnensis ΔC (BN3001) single mutants were replaced by an unmarked in-frame deletion obtained by FLP-mediated excision of the disruption cassette (62).
